en.value: Having conversations in a variety of working environments - Making requests and giving permission
People talk about work a lot! Now we’re going to learn some useful words and phrases for talking about an average day at work. Here’s a taster of the things we’ll learn to say.
I have a meeting first thing tomorrow morning.
May I work from home on Thursday afternoon?
I emailed him but he never replied.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
I have a meeting first thing tomorrow morning.
We can also say "to be in a meeting". Compare the two examples below.
She is in a meeting from 3 p.m. to 4 p.m.
They are having a meeting at the moment.
to be at his desk / to be at her desk
She's not at her desk at the moment.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
She's not [k]at her desk[/k] at the moment.
Match the beginning and the end of the phrase.
to ask someone to do something
Did you ask Enrico to help you?
Select the words in the correct order.
I emailed him but he never replied.
I [k]called[/k] you yesterday. Did you get my message?
We can also say "to give someone a call" and "to send someone an email".
Please, give him a call tomorrow morning.
Sure. I'll send an email to update you.
May I work from home on Thursday afternoon?
He's off sick with the flu.
We decided to book some time off work.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
What might you say when you want to have a few days off?
I’d like to book some time off.
I’d like to work from home.
I’d like to be off sick.
Shall we have a chat about it later?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Can I have a [k]c[/k][k]h[/k][k]a[/k][k]t[/k] with you later?
Have another look at all the expressions we've learned:
to have a meeting / to be in a meeting
to call / to give someone a call
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Nick wants to book some time off work.
Ummm… yes, but I think he [k]has a meeting[/k].
Oh, ok. I’m going home now, but I wanted to [k]have a chat[/k] with him.
Well, I need to book some [k]time off[/k]. Family stuff…
Oh, right. You could send him an [k]email[/k].
Maybe… actually, could you ask him to [k]give[/k] me a call later?
Which of these sentences means that the person is not at work?
Jonah's not [k]at[/k] [k]his[/k] desk at the moment.
Listen to the audio. Select the most accurate statement.
Nick wanted to have a chat with his boss.
Nick wanted to book some time off work.
Nick wanted to send his boss an email.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
Where is Nancy? Select the most accurate statement.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Fill in the gap using the image.
I [k]sent him an email|gave him a call|called him|emailed him[/k] but he never replied.
Imagine you need to ask your boss for some time off. What might you say? Write or record your response.
Hi there, can I have a quick chat ...? I think I'll be working from home most of the week.

In this unit, we'll learn some different ways of asking for permission, as well as a few ways of giving permission. This sort of language is very useful in an office environment, but it also comes in handy in other social situations, such as at a friend's house, a dinner party or in a restaurant. Remember that "you" in English can be formal or informal, so the phrases in this unit can all be used in both formal and informal situations.
Do you mind if I work from home on Monday?
Is it OK if I leave at five today?
A lot of the phrases in this unit are synonymous. There are lots of ways of asking for and giving permission in English.
Do you mind if I use your bathroom?
Is it OK if I use your bathroom?
Do you mind if I stay at your house?
This is another way of saying "Is it OK if I stay at your house?"
May I have another drink, please?

There are different ways of asking for permission. You can use the words "can", "may" and "could" to make polite requests. In general, "can" is slightly more informal than "could" and "may". Don't forget to add "please", which will make your request more polite.
Is it OK if I leave at 5 today?
Do you mind if I join you?
Can you tell me where the post office is?
May I have a glass of water, please?
Which is the more informal way of asking for a pen?
Let's now have a look at some typical responses to requests. We can use them all in most situations, whether formal or casual.
Of course you can work from home.
Select the answer you hear in the audio.
Sorry, dad, I can't talk right now.
I can't talk to you right now.
we can talk about it later.
Select the answer you hear in the audio.
[k]Is it OK if|Is it okay if[/k] I work from home today?
Michelle wants another drink. Type the missing verb.
[k]Do you mind|Is it ok|is it okay[/k] if I call you later?
[k]Sorry|sorry|I'm sorry[/k], you can't use this meeting room. We're using it.
Your friend calls you, but you are busy and can't talk. Ask your friend to contact you later.
Could you ...? Is it ok if ...? Do you mind if ...?
